sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Hypertension: initial, 4 mg ORALLY twice daily
  • Hypertension: titrate to maintenance, may increase in increments of 4-8 mg/day ORALLY at 1-2 wk intervals
  • Hypertension: MAX 32 mg ORALLY twice daily

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Safety and effectiveness have not been established in children,

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• liver disease: dosage adjustments may be required (specific guidelines unavailable)
  • withdrawal schedule: patients receiving 48 mg/day or greater should be tapered off over a 7- to 10-day period

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Hypertension
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Hypertension, Perioperative; Prophylaxis
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• avoid abrupt withdrawal (rebound hypertension)
  • cerebrovascular disease
  • liver disease
  • myocardial infarction (recent)
  • renal impairment
  • sedation
  • severe coronary insufficiency

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Guanabenz: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Chest pain (3% or less), Edema (3% or less)
  • Gastrointestinal:Xerostomia (12% to 37%)
  • Neurologic:Asthenia (4% to 10%), Sedated (20% to 50%), Somnolence (20%-50%)
Serious
Cardiovascular:Cardiac dysrhythmia (3% or less)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Guanabenz acetate is an antihypertensive agent and a derivative of aminoguanidine. Its antihypertensive effect is mediated by the stimulation of the centrally active alpha adrenergic receptors which results in a decreased sympathetic outflow at the bulbar level to the peripheral circulatory system from the brain.

0.title: Absorption
0.mono:
• Oral: time to peak concentration, 2 h to 5 h
  • Bioavailability: 75%
  • Effect of food: none

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
GUANABENZ
OVERDOSE: similar to clonidine: hypotension, bradycardia, respiratory depression, somnolence, and miosis. Transient early hypertension. WITHDRAWAL: Diaphoresis, nervousness, palpitations, insomnia, malaise, abdominal cramps, and elevated diastolic BP 16 to 48 hours after abrupt withdrawal.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
GUANABENZ
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal, gastric lavage.
  • Hypotensive episode: IV 0.9% NaCl, dopamine, norepinephrine.
  • Naloxone: Inconclusive, may treat hypotension, apnea, CNS depression. DOSE - Adult/Child 2 mg IV. Repeat as needed.
  • Bradycardia: Atropine. Adult 0.5 to 1 mg; Pediatric 0.02 mg/kg; repeat in 3-5 min. MAXIUM DOSE - Adult 2 mg, Child 0.5 mg IV.
  • Monitoring of patient: ECG, vital signs, pulse oximetry.
  • Hypertensive episode: Usually transient; do not treat unless end organ effects present. Nitroprusside 0.5 mcg/kg/min titrate to effect.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
GUANABENZ
Data limited. Hypotension and bradycardia reported after 160 to 320 mg in adults, 4 mg in a child.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Patient should avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause somnolence.
  • This drug may cause xerostomia or anxiety.
  • Advise patient against sudden discontinuation of drug, as this may precipitate rebound hypertension.
  • Patient should avoid drinking alcohol during therapy.
